When the Regional Planning Council was established in 1963 by the State Legislature, it was charged with
preparing a General Development Plan for the Baltimore Region. The purpose of this plan is best stated by the Act
which established the Council: ”An opportunity must be provided for the several units of government within the area
to work together with the State and private agencies toward the solution of their problems. In order to deal with these
matters on a rational and sound basis, they must be considered within the framework of a general development plan
for the area.” (Article 78D, Section 1.) Additionally, the Act establishes the general contents of the plan, as follows:
”The plan shall be based upon comprehensive surveys and studies of land use, transportation, public utilities,
governmental facilities and services, and natural resources. It shall take into account social and economic factors,
conditions, and trends that are relevant to the probable future development of the area.” (Article 78D, Section 12, (a).)

All three prior General Development Plans have followed this general outline while varying in thrust and de-
tail to meet the major issues of regional importance at the time of their preparation. The 1982 General Development
Plan is no exception and addresses the problems of implementing necessary programs in a time of reduced fiscal
resources, declining growth and a sluggish economy. The how and what to implement is the single most important
issue facing the state, region, and local governments at this time. Establishment of priorities, both in terms of
programs and facilities, is critical and must be matched by the means to secure the funds to pay for them. High
interest rates are making it more difficult for the state and local governments to raise funds for capital projects and
have also affected business expansion and formation with depressing effects on tax revenues. Additionally,
decreasing federal financial assistance is placing increased burdens on state and local resources.

Unfortunately, while revenue sources are decreasing or becoming more expensive to obtain, demands for
government expenditures are as high, or higher, than ever. In the era of rapid suburban growth following the Second
World War, enormous expenditures for new public facilities of all kinds were required to keep pace with needs, while
funds for maintenance of existing facilities were reduced. The facilities built during the fifties and sixties are in need
of repair and, in some cases, enlargement, while the other facilities on which maintenance had been deferred are in
great need of repair and, in many cases, replacement. Additionally, many older communities need revitalization and
new facilities.

In addressing these and other problems, many of which are not related to the physical facilities of the region but
to the social and economic needs of the residents, the Regional Planning Council has concentrated on seven major
areas of concern, i.e., Transportation, Economic Development, Housing, Land Use, Energy, Environment, and
Human Services. Each area of concern defines the most critical problems, examines program and project priorities,
and suggests a number of ways by which the necessary funding can be obtained. Following this analysis, a series of
goals are established with accompanying policies and strategies to achieve these goals. In many respects, the point of
view of this GDP is shorter than the usual 20 year range of previous plans as it is more involved with the short range (5
-10 years) view associated with plan and program implementation. However, many of the goals are long range in
nature and will require a considerable length of time before they can be achieved. On May 27, 1982, Governor Hughes
issued an Executive Order containing 72 major policies which will be used by state agencies as they make decisions
affecting development in Maryland. The goals and policies of the General Development Plan are consistent with and
serve to reaffirm and support the policies of the Executive Order.

In the following discussion, each of the areas of concern will be summarized with particular reference to the
issues and goals. These summaries are necessarily very brief and contain only the most critical issues, goals, and
findings. The reader interested in the policies and strategies developed to reach the recommended goals is referred to
the pertinent volumes which accompany this summary or to the volume of goals and policies which contains all of

the policies and strategies recommended by the Regional Planning Council.

J. Hugh Nichols
Chairman, Regional Planning Council

the goals and policies of the 1982 General Development Plan. Major policy areas,
shown in color, are:

Suburban Service Area - planned future urban growth areas with
necessary public facilities.

Open Space and Recreation - public parks, natural areas, and other
permanent open space.

Rural Service Area - intended for exclusion of urban growth and reserved
for agriculture, forestry, and related activities.

Agricultural Preservation Districts - areas within the Rural Servicé Area
where local governments are acquiring easements to preserve
agricultural land. '

Superimposed, in black, upon these major areas are a number of special areas.
While seemingly unrelated, all of these special areas have an impact on the type or
form of development which can be accommodated. These special areas are:

il

State Critical Areas - designated by the Department of State Planning.
Water Resources Protection Areas - development should be carefully
controlled to protect quality of surface water reservoirs or ground water
resources.

Airport Noise District - restrictions required on development due to
aircraft noise.

Air Quality Management Area - non-attainment area for particulate (dust)
standards with restrictions on industrial development.

Historic Preservation Districts - historic and/or architecturally
significant areas.

Water Quality Growth Caution Areas - portions of the Suburban Service
Area requiring particular care to prevent pollution of surface or ground
water resources.

A number of existing or planned transportation facilities are also shown:

1

Highway and Transit Facilities - new interstate and other highway and
transit projects on new locations which are programmed for construction
or project planning; does not include widening, resurfacing, or similar

improvements.



In contrast to prior General Development Plans which
contained major land use analyses and recommendations, the
1982 Plan restricts itself to an examination of the degree to which
local and regional plans are being implemented. Since 1977, all
of the jurisdictions in the region have revised or adopted plans
containing the concepts of centralized development and growth
management which were the major precepts of the 1977 General
Development Plan. As a result, the major land use goals were
considered to be valid and are included in the 1982 Plan. The
basic development goal is as follows:

THE REGION’S RESOURCES SHOULD BE
MANAGED TO PROMOTE AND ACHIEVE A MORE
CENTRALIZED DEVELOPMENT PATTERN.
SIMULTANEOUSLY, PUBLIC ACTIONS SHOULD
BE DESIGNED TO ENHANCE, MAINTAIN, AND
REVITALIZE EXISTING COMMUNITIES. PUBLIC
POLICIES SHOULD ENCOURAGE THE GROWTH
OF METROCENTER AND OTHER TOWN AND
COMMUNITY CENTERS. THE RURAL SERVICE
AREA SHOULD BE PRESERVED FOR FARMING
AND FORESTRY, PUBLIC WATERSHED
PROTECTION AND MAJOR PUBLIC PARKLAND,
AND NEW WELL-PLANNED DEVELOPMENT
SHOULD UTILIZE LAND RESOURCES WITHIN
EXISTING COMMUNITIES AND IN CAREFULLY
STAGED NEW GROWTH AREAS IN SEQUENCE
WITH THE ORDERLY PROVISION OF PUBLIC
SERVICES AND FACILITIES. BALTIMORE CITY
SHOULD RECEIVE A GREATER SHARE OF THE
REGION’S GROWTH.

With general agreement as to development form and
location, the critical element is the degree to which this
development pattern is being achieved, with particular reference
to the provision and scheduling of public facilities. The ability
to acquire the necessary capital resources to provide these
facilities is also a key issue addressed by the 1982 General
Development Plan. These issues were addressed by examining
the means by which the local governments in the region are
considering or are using innovative techniques to provide
capital resources including greater cooperation with the private
sector, and by examining the degree to which the plans and
programs for sewerage and transportation facilities serve to meet
the development goals of the local jurisdictions.

A wide range of development policies exists in the region
together with measures designed to implement them. In
implementing these policies local governments have become
dependent, to varying degrees, on infusion of federal and state
financing required to subsidize urban renewal and support the
construction, reconstruction, and maintenance of public facility
systems. The withdrawal, or substantial reduction of federal aid,
threatens severe cutbacks in development policy
implementation. This analysis represents an initial attempt to
define how the various jurisdictions intend or are coping with

these realities. The following observations have resulted from
this preliminary investigation:

B ILarger amounts of private capital may become
available to help undertake all phases of land
development, including basic infrastructure, than in
the past. Developers with access to large sources of
investment funds, coupled with a vested interest in
the region, can open varied new routes to community
development. This has occurred in the past and is
currently the best potential source of private
assistance.

B Public support and participation in development
ventures, through traditional as well as innovative
activities, will continue as a basic requirement.
Coordinated planning and programming within and
among public facility systems are requisites to the
staging and financing of growth.

B Opportunities for coventuré between local
governments and representatives of the private sector
should be solicited. Negotiation of individual and
joint responsibilities are critical to all phases of such
undertakings, including the creation of mechanisms
to handle features such as multi-source funding and
cost-sharing arrangements.

B Measures for recovery of capital investments
equitably, without devastation of the market, are
essential. Return to some forms of long term, below
marketing financing, with recovery spread over a
broad revenue base, seems preferable to short term
loading of capital costs solely on new homebuyers.

B Careful use of innovative capital financing
techniques, such as sale-leaseback, can relieve public
financial problems in some cases, releasing
traditional governmental powers to assume fiscal
obligations elsewhere.

Baltimore City occupies a unique position in the
metropolitan area and its problems are those normally
associated with renewal and revitalization. Great strides have
been made in meeting many of these needs using combinations
of federal, state, local, and private funds as well as varied
institutional arrangements. These efforts are exemplified by
Charles Center, the Inner Harbor and Harborplace, and the
Convention Center. A great deal remains to be done throughout
the city and particularly with the vast system of sewer and water
lines, roads, and bridges. As an example of the magnitude of this
problem, some $600 million will be required for wastewater
system maintenance and replacement alone without considering
any other portions of the infrastructure. The city intends to use a
number of ”creative capital funding” measures to meet these
needs including ”sale-leaseback” in which the city will sell a
particular facility to a private investor then lease it back. The
investor is able to benefit from tax write-offs, credits, and
depreciation allowances. No matter how creative, however, most
programs will still be dependent upon state and federal
assistance as well as the traditional fiscal operations.

Another section of the land use analysis “Coordination of
Sewerage and Transportation Investments for Regional
Development” investigates the degree to which major public
investments in sewerage and transportation facilities serve to
support and enhance regional and local development policies.
This work is intended to identify those planned growth areas in
the region which will need new or enlarged facilities in order to
meet local development goals.

The analysis used Regional Planning Districts (RPD) as
the means of identifying growth areas, although in many cases
only a portion of those rather large areas would contain planned
urban growth. A total of 38 RPDs (out of a total of 94 RPDs in
the region) were selected for analysis. Together they account for
89.7% and 76.1% of the projected 1980-1990 population and

employment growth respectively. Existing development
activity, 1978-1980, was then examined using Baltimore Gas and
Electric Company connection data and Regional Planning
Council employment data. The final step was to analyze the
adequacy of both the sewer and transportation systems to
support the demands of the projected growth.

This analysis was done on a very general level and
included planned and programmed facilities and their
approximate times of completion, in order to arrive at general
levels of adequacy to meet growth needs. It must be remembered
that this provides only a guide to facility needs and will be most
useful in future studies to determine project priorities.

Findings of this study indicate that only five of the thirty-
eight RPDs selected for analysis have severe sewerage and/or
transportation system deficiencies. These areas are not evenly
spread throughout the region but are concentrated in Anne
Arundel and Carroll counties, and while they account for only
15.5% of the region’s projected population growth they are
planned to contain 32% of Anne Arundel County and 46% of
Carroll County’s growth.

The bulk of the RPDs examined (26) show problems from
either sewerage system or transportation facility inadequacy and
are fairly evenly distributed throughout the region. Due to the
fact that these areas account for 60.6% and 76% of the region’s
projected population and employment growth respectively, it is
important to carefully program the facilities necessary to correct
system deficiencies.

Results of this study indicate that there are a number of
critical facility problems which must be addressed if the region
and its local governments are to realize their development
objectives. Additionally, it will not be possible to eliminate all of
these deficiencies in the next few years due to funding and other
constraints. While this analysis, which is only a first look at
these problems on a regional level, is by no means definitive it
should prove to be a valuable tool in assisting the state, regional,
and local governments in better defining their facility
construction priorities in the future.



Since the preparation of the 1977 General Development
Plan, there have been some very significant changes in
conditions underlying Baltimore’s future economic prospects.
Some have been positive:

B The transformation of Baltimore’s Inner Harbor
from an wurban eyesore to an internationally
recognized revitalization site.

® The opening of the Convention Center, Harborplace,
and the National Aquarium generated new
employment and further diversified the local
economy.

B Major construction projects, such as the Baltimore
Metro and Ft. McHenry Tunnel, will enhance the
movement of people and goods throughout the
region.

B Worldwide energy demand has enhanced Baltimore’s

position as one of the leading United States coal ports
with a multi-million dollar infusion of capital into
the Port.

Some have been negative:

m The long term trend away from the production of
goods is accelerating with continued dislocation of
workers from economic sectors long basic to this
area’s economy.

B Government service employment, which once served
to cushion declines in industry, has been declining
since the late 1970s.

B The consequences of new economic policies in
Washington, featuring tight monetary policy and
shifting of responsibility from federal to state local
governments are still uncertain.

® Unemployment has continued to increase
particularly among blacks.

As a result of these and other changes, the 1982 General

Development Plan has focussed on a few important issues which
can be effectively addressed by state and local decision makers.

Issue: Capturing a Share of Growth Industries

As an indication of the changes which have been
occurring in the Baltimore economy, the following table shows
the changes in employment, as percentages of total regional
employment, in the major economic sectors which have
occurred since 1960 and projected to the year 2000.

SOURCE: Regional Planning Council estimates and projections.

The table clearly shows the continuing decline of
employment in the Manufacturing sector and the rather
dramatic increase in the Service sector. An important point to
bear in mind is that there are a number of bright spots in the
Manufacturing sector such as electronics and
telecommunications which are among the so-called “high tech”
industries. It is recommended that every effort be made to attract
these growth industries to the region by emphasizing the
advantages of the Baltimore area in terms of its existing
institutions such as The Johns Hopkins Applied Physics
Laboratory, the Space Telescope Institute now under
development, the major medical institutions, and the proximity
of other federal research institutions.

While the wholesale/retail activities, represented by the
Trade sector are a fairly stable component of the regional
economy, its status can be improved by increasing activity in the
Port of Baltimore and additional gains associated with the
tourism/convention activity centered in the Inner Harbor.

Since the preparation of the 1977 General Development
Plan, there have been some very significant changes in
conditions underlying Baltimore’s future economic prospects.
Some have been positive:

B The transformation of Baltimore’s Inner Harbor
from an wurban eyesore to an internationally
recognized revitalization site.

® The opening of the Convention Center, Harborplace,
and the National Aquarium generated new
employment and further diversified the local
economy.

B Major construction projects, such as the Baltimore
Metro and Ft. McHenry Tunnel, will enhance the
movement of people and goods throughout the
region.

B Worldwide energy demand has enhanced Baltimore’s

position as one of the leading United States coal ports
with a multi-million dollar infusion of capital into
the Port.

Some have been negative:

m The long term trend away from the production of
goods is accelerating with continued dislocation of
workers from economic sectors long basic to this
area’s economy.

B Government service employment, which once served
to cushion declines in industry, has been declining
since the late 1970s.

B The consequences of new economic policies in
Washington, featuring tight monetary policy and
shifting of responsibility from federal to state local
governments are still uncertain.

® Unemployment has continued to increase
particularly among blacks.

As a result of these and other changes, the 1982 General

Development Plan has focussed on a few important issues which
can be effectively addressed by state and local decision makers.

The table clearly shows the continuing decline of

bear in mind is that there are a number of bright spots in the
Manufacturing sector such as electronics and

these growth industries to the region by emphasizing the
advantages of the Baltimore area in terms of its existing
institutions such as The Johns Hopkins Applied Physics
Laboratory, the Space Telescope Institute now under
development, the major medical institutions, and the proximity
of other federal research institutions.
